title-group.subtitle: The Privatization of the Media Time Sphere

author-notes.corresp: Mira Moshe, Ariel University Center of Samaria, 108 H Tavor Street, PO Box 1543, Shoham, 1543, Israel Email: moshemi@mail.biu.ac.il

fn.p: Mira Moshe is a senior lecturer in the Sociology and Anthropology Department and the Mass Communication School in Ariel University Center of Samaria. Her academic work has mainly focused on media regulation, television, culture, time, and society.

abstract.p: Lately, the sense of chronic time pressure promotes the need for a reexamination of media temporal configuration. The basic assumption of this article is that the spread of neoliberalist ideas, together with technological innovations (e.g., digital TV, digital remote control, and digital video recorder), has encouraged the privatization of media time, leading to the experience of media time squeezing. To be more concrete, multichannel applications allow control over viewing schedules, time settings, and time flow. But while the diffusion of digital technological platforms has made privatization of the television time sphere possible, the regulation of these technologies is based on state time management subject to traditional, linear, nontechnological principles. Moreover, even though neoliberalism facilitates systematic deregulation and privatization in the arena of television and new media, one cannot overlook the dualism sustained between technological vision and cultural substantiation.

body.p: Time squeezing may be defined as one of the structural characteristics of contemporary society. Individuals who spend their daily life trying to compress a maximum amount of activities into a given time unit endeavor to squeeze the greatest quantity of media content into given time intervals.

The spread of neoliberalist ideas, in conjunction with technological innovations and multichannel applications (e.g., digital TV, digital remote control, and digital video recorder), has encouraged the privatization of media time, leading to the experience of media time squeezing.

“Time squeeze” and notions of “rush” and “harried” are popular concerns in modern and postmodern societies (Southerton 2003). Time squeeze is a phrase often used to describe contemporary concerns about a shortage of time and an acceleration of the pace of everyday life (Southerton and Tomlinson 2006). The concept of time squeeze is linked to the speeding up of our existence and the development of time-saving technological innovations, in addition to increasing stress and role overload. As a result, in almost all areas of our urban lifestyle—work, leisure, family, childhood, adolescence, and so on—we are witness to an ongoing attempt, either real or imagined, to squeeze time (Jarvis 2005). The steady increase in labor hours and the growing complexity of consumer activities that demand more and more time (Schor 1992), in addition to the need for an immediate response on a global and network level twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week (Southerton 2003), cause people to sense that the time available to them is inadequate for their existence (Florida 2002). Hence, time squeezing clears the way and makes room for more tasks (Schor 1992; Hochschild 1997; Robinson and Godbey 1999; Ciulla 2000).

Although individuals are “blamed” for the time squeezing phenomenon, it is clearly one of the modern urban problems that do not stem from individual idiosyncrasies (Giddens 1984; Jarvis, Pratt, and Cheng-Chong Wu 2001; Southerton 2003). Yet despite being a structural difficulty, the solutions available present themselves on an individual, personal level. That is, people are required to create their own personal adjustment mechanisms to cope with time pressure. For example, women tend to engage in multitasking activities or to perform a large number of actions simultaneously for the sake of handling a large number of household- or job-related duties within time frames that are constantly shrinking (Hochschild 1997; Sullivan 1997; Thompson 1996). Men, on the other hand, tend to seek additional employment to fill the widening gap between family expenses and income (Dempster-McClain and Moen 1989). Efforts to increase workload to augment income are part of dealing with “life cycle squeeze” (Wilenski 1963; Schorr 1966; Oppenheimer 1974, 1979, 1982), resulting in employment invading the home (Hogarth et al. 2001). Of course, couples with children who have full-time jobs are most severely affected by the need to manage time (Jacobs and Gerson 2001; Van der Lippe 2007).

Despite the fact that the occupational sphere is not the only one demanding time squeeze, it is the least flexible to change (Clarkberg and Moen 2001; Kraaykamp, Van Gils, and Van der Lippe 2009); thus, the job environment has been the most widely researched. However, to deal with the sense of urgency aroused by time squeeze, it is necessary to recognize the many dimensions of the concept and its various implications (Southerton and Tomlinson 2006).

sec.title: Neoliberalism and Media Technology
sec.p: The desire to squeeze time is evoked as a result of the individual’s tendency to compare his or her standard of living and quality of life with those of others, out of ambition to arrive at the same quality of life.

disp-quote.p: In all cases pressures to “keep up,” to have a lifestyle or a standard of life comparable to those of others within one’s networks, were identified as the fundamental sources of a “time squeeze.” (Southerton 2003, 9)

sec.p: The neoliberal approach has expanded individuals’ expectations of prosperity, luxuriousness, extravagance, and lavishness. Neoliberalism broadly means the enactment of an economic and social transformation under the aegis of the free market (Connell, Fawcett, and Meagher 2009). It has transformed society into an “enterprise society” based on the free market, competition, inequality, and individual privilege. It elaborates the strategies of “individualization, insecuritization and depoliticization” (Lazzarato 2009, 10). It has introduced systematic deregulation and privatization that have tilted the balance in favor of the power of “capital” and devastated the poor (Venn 2009).

Foucault held the state responsible for the distribution of financial and social power by means of taking control of the environment and curbing the independence of individuals. The neoliberal individual is not a sovereign subject, nor a moral subject, nor the subject of law (Massumi 2009). Adopting a neoliberal stance—identified more with the conservative Right than with the liberal Left—(Scott 2009) has adversely affected weaker populations, such as the elderly (Asquith 2009), women (Connell, Fawcett, and Meagher 2009), and others, as Western society and culture have subordinated themselves to financial squeeze (Burawoy 2009).

The notion of neoliberalism has been spread through popular culture, especially television broadcasts, framing the market as a natural medium for bartering services and assets and as a means of increasing expectations regarding a desirable financial status and the accumulation of worldly goods (Strinati 2000). The dissemination of leisure (and pleasure), culture, quality, and standard of living has been strengthened considerably by the expansion of cable and satellite television (Palmer 2008). The commercial trends behind multichannel television have created a glut of programs organized around concepts of consumer capitalism of the “makeover” type, self-actualization fantasies, and so on (Andrew and Carter 2008). Accordingly, it has turned out that although cable television broadcasts have increased the potential for cultural diversity (Strinati 2000), this is not evident in nationwide programs focusing on lifestyle (Davey 1985). In fact, the multichannel broadcasting industry has been universally pressured to relate to the viewer as a business commodity (Berry 2009). Furthermore, cable and satellite TV broadcasts have developed a tremendous range of possibilities (Neuendorf, Jeffres, and Atkin 2000), which have raised the average number of viewing hours and transformed TV watching habits and schedules (Pfetsch, Schönbach, and Kuteroff 1989; Gunter 1989) while creating a plethora of varied lifestyle channels to satisfy a wide range of viewer interests and needs (Rosengren 1994).1 This wide range of programs is distributed by worldwide media systems that have greatly expanded, as have the enormous numbers of cable and satellite TV consumers (Smith-Shomade 2004; Nam 2008; Garitaonandía and Garmendia 2009). By means of segmenting content (narrowcasting) and addressing niche audiences, numerous groups, especially economically successful audiences (Eastman, Head, and Klein 1985), can easily find content that meets their needs. Indeed, it seems that the cost entailed in purchasing media information technology has made it available and acceptable chiefly to the upper classes (Golding and Murdock 1986; Tudor 2009). In effect, directing cable and satellite TV to affluent audiences has served to further widen existent socioeconomic disparities (Schejter 2009).

The promise of plenty intrinsic to the distribution of digital information services, media technology, and innovative media services (Mansell 1999) has also been linked to changes in perceptions of time and space (Bovet and Këllezi 2008). Furthermore, it has aroused awareness of the interaction between producer and consumer, accelerated the death of television (Gilder 1992), and aided in determining the tenor of existence in a neoliberal, global world (Dal Yong 2007). In this new age, people can order what they want to see whenever they want to see it, no longer needing to settle for what is available for viewing. We can actually compile a private “playlist” (Turner 2009) by means of video on demand (VOD) technology (Ling, Nilsen, and Granhaung 1999), DVD technology (Garitaonandía and Garmendia 2009), and so on. The assimilation of new media technologies into the homes of media consumers is the result of symbolic cultural manipulations (Ling, Nilsen, and Granhaung 1999), the self-definition of the individual and his or her family in a wider social context (Ling, Nilsen, and Granhaung 1999), negotiation among family members (Silverstone and Haddon 1996), the degree to which family members identify with the accepted cultural conventions of their era (Gullestad 1984), and also the ability of individuals to manage their own time sphere dimension.

sec.title: Neoliberalism, Time Squeezing, and Media Consumption
sec.p: The consumption of communications technology in quotidian life, both indoors and outdoors, has traditionally been comprehended as an intermediary strategy bridging the private and public spheres while redefining time perceptions (Silverstone 1993; Scannell 1986, 1988, 1996). Yet temporal evaluations, the acceleration of time flow and rhythms, time squeezing, and media consumption squeezing reshape this act of mediation between the private and the public. In the media industry, the act of squeezing is usually of an economic nature, resulting in negative consequences for communications. Financial concerns are constantly present, hence causing individuals to squeeze as much profit as possible out of their financial outlay (Bouwman and Van Der Duin 2007). As a result, public interest in television programs is squeezed, strongly affecting the program market (Puppis 2008). Economic forces acting on European public broadcasting, for instance, endeavor to squeeze it and limit its borders (Bardoel and d’Haenens 2008). Hence, fewer and fewer resources are apportioned to news coverage, and the viewer is exposed to inferior news reportage (Heikkilä and Kunelius 2008). At the same time, dramas, soap operas, and comedies often use media squeezing by presenting stereotypical characters. This stereotypization is often unavoidable since television squeezes “reality” into the present, allowing the viewer to easily identify with social reality (Castelló 2009). It seems, then, that media squeeze enhances producers’ industrial motivations to maximize profits while minimizing costs through squeezing resources and content. Yet one cannot ignore the diffusion of media squeezing into the habitat of domestic media consumption.
Media time squeezing is closely linked to the innovation of a wide range of new media, for example, digital TV, the digital remote control, and the digital video recorder.

sec.title: The Remote Control
sec.p: The analog remote control was developed as early as the 1950s (Morris and Forgette 2007) and was perceived as a tool that enhanced the passivity of the viewer (who with its help could become a “couch potato”; Costello and Moore 2007). In the 1960s the analog remote control was characteristic of expensive television sets, but during the 1980s the remote control became standard equipment, allowing the creation of self-governing subjects and objects and redefining time, space, and possibilities of mobility and privacy (Hay 2000). With time, digitalization transformed the remote control from a viewing instrument to an interactive tool, which made it possible to perform a range of functions while watching television. This resulted in the transition from passive to active watching (Andrejevic 2008) and from viewing to real-time consuming of products, by means of the remote, and even gambling (Kruse 2009). Simple hand-held remote control users may access a multitude of information services—weather information, music channels, financial information, and more (Frenette and Caron 1995). To a large degree, while the development of the wireless remote privatized control over television viewing and radio listening (Fuqua 2003), the invention of the digital remote control introduced various options that made media time squeezing possible.

sec.title: VCR
sec.p: The first public introduction of the Ampex analog videotape recorder occurred in 1956. A decade and a half later, in the early 1970s, the ability to record television shows was offered to consumers (Secunda 1990). Technology’s impact on the audiovisual cultural industries was compounded by the introduction of new stand-alone devices that could be attached to the home television set. Stand-alone refers to products that can be operated without being linked to a continuous feed of programming or data distributed from a central source over the air or via cable or telephone (Lyman 1983). Time shifting was originally the primary motive for analog VCR ownership. Time shifting means that activities can be shifted from times when “shortage” is experienced to times when “surplus” is perceived. People use the video recorder to move the time they watch a particular television show from one when other activities are being pursued to a less demanding period (Kaufman-Scarborough and Lindquist 2003). This function provided the consumer with a significant gain in flexibility over the time when programs could be viewed (Komiya and Litman 1990). Still, at first the VCR did create a revolution in the way people used media and only freshened up habitual television consumption (Levy 1987, 1989). Yet evidence suggests that although the primary innovation offered by video technology—in particular VCRs—was the ability to selectively play back prerecorded programs, since the 1990s the VCR has functioned predominately as a domestic extension of the film industry (Kompare 2006). The VCR also paved the way for a “home theater” adapted to the viewer’s needs and budget (Yoder 1998), which had been articulated to a range of aesthetic and ideological preferences (Bjarkman 2004). Thus, the VCR laid the foundation for media time squeezing.

sec.title: Digital Television
sec.p: Digital television transmits and receives broadcast television signals that by using combinations of zeros and ones represent all sorts of data (Weber and Evans 2002). But “digital television is much more than a tale of technological innovation. It is a story about large-scale changes in the normative models, as well as the institutions that shape television as an economic and social force—and, ultimately, about the politics of the information society,” as Galperin (2004, 4) wrote. Digital television offers “interactive” choices conterminous with computer interfaces (Wood 2007), increases functionality of services, delivers a range of new applications, including interactive services and online connectivity to the home (Sourbati 2004), and improves viewing quality. It lowers transaction costs by bettering efficiency of spectrum use, as more data can be transmitted within the same bandwidth (Iosifidis 2006). Digital television not only provides the promise of interactive services but also presents long tail-based business models. Furthermore, digital television services act as an alternative gateway, delivering culture to a wider audience (Evens et al. 2010).

Similar to the way digital devices compress and facilitate information within a very short time duration (Hope 2006), new media via cables or satellite reconstruct media temporal configurations by the acceleration and compression of time. It seems that digital technologies that allow time shifting from one medium to another (Bjarkman 2004; Cai 2005; Carlson 2006; Huang 2007) tend to create “digital time” (Ladner 2009) and privatize the media time sphere.

sec.title: Media Time Squeezing
sec.p: The privatization of the media time sphere enables self-governing and self-controlling over time. Time-saving technologies facilitate better handling of a time shortage as well as supporting the experience of media time squeezing. Media time squeezing refers to pressures to “keep up” with multichannel media affluence and handle a shortage of time by self-constructing viewing schedules, time flow, and time rhythm.

sec.title: Self-Constructing of Viewing Schedules
sec.p: The first feature of time sphere squeezing is the privatization of media schedules, that is, the transition from synchronic to asynchronic media consumption. Similar to the way the VCR introduced “stand-alone” device, the digital remote control operates as a “pseudo stand-alone” application. It makes it possible to break the dependency on the continuous feed of programming or data distributed from a central source. When one is not obligated to “keep up” with an external time flow and can self-synchronize one’s viewing schedule, it become easier to cope with an overflow of broadcasts. Furthermore, self-synchronizing of the viewing timetable allows the reconstruction of temporal coexistence, that is, restructuring a temporal harmonization that makes temporal hegemony possible. Temporal hegemony is defined as “the dominance of certain ideas of what time should be and mean” (Roe, Waller, and Clegg 2008, 13). When temporal hegemony is operating, “one part may impose its own view of time on others and may demand conformance with its preferred temporal regime, thus establishing temporal hegemony” (Roe, Waller, and Clegg 2008, 15). However, while the transition to multichannel digital broadcasting permits media consumers to determine programming time schedules to achieve self-gratification, this results in a lessening of the need for synchronizing private with organized broadcasting, leading to a synchronization of media consumption and temporal heterogeneity. In the new media age, it is no longer necessary to view programs as they are broadcast or to synchronize clocks and schedules between transmitters and receivers. Therefore, self-constructing the viewing schedule presents the opportunity to handle the shortage of time by squeezing the external time flow into the internal, unique, private time zone.

sec.title: Self-Construction of Time Flow
sec.p: The second feature of media time squeezing is the privatization of time flow direction, that is, the transition from unidirectional time flow (from present to future) to multidirectional time flow, from present to future and from present to past. The flow of time is generally represented as moving from past to future (Rawls 2005; Moshe 2009), and time flow is manifested in a frame-dependent way (McCall 1976). But when time is treated as an individual experience, it is generally described as having a primarily inner dimension in the flow of experience and is treated as unidirectional and related to individual projects and goals (Rawls 2005). The start-over button, for instance, liberates viewers and allows them to begin a program anew. By using the start-over button, the user can exercise control over the experience of media consumption (Robinson 2009). The start-over function thus presents another chance, a new approach, and the promise of a brighter future (Kimball and O’Neil 2001; Hoey 2005) and the fear that it is sometimes too late for a fresh start (Albrook 1969). As long as a particular program is being broadcast, it is possible to start it over again, thus combining synchronic and asynchronic broadcasting schedules. An additional way to control time flow is by using the rewind function. To rewind means to reverse the direction of a roll of magnetic tape or various types of film. This term has outlived physical spool-based media and is now also applied to digital media. The rewind function also makes it possible to control time (Davidson 2008). It broadens the possibilities open to the consumer (Coyle 2000) since it provides the ability to repeat his or her favorite segments (Brown 2007) and to control viewing content (Langill 2009) and direction of time flow. In fact, while digitalization facilitates time shifting from one medium to another, the start-over bottoms along with the rewind function obtain time shifting within a medium and operate as time-saving technology. As a result, one can squeeze various programs into a given time interval and space out media consumption by embracing self-construction of time flow.

sec.title: Self-Constructing Time Rhythm
sec.p: The third feature of time sphere squeezing is the privatization of media time rhythm. Just as neoliberal ideology encouraged the consumer to step up his or her rate of consumption, the application of digital media technology encourages the traditional TV consumer to increase viewing rhythm. This may be done by means of zapping among various channels and by controlling the pace by which programs are run. Zapping introduces the ability to edit programs by skipping segments that the consumer chooses not to watch (Dawson 2007). This could include parts of programs that do not interest the viewer (Kilker 2003), commercials (Sherlock 2009), and unwanted political information (Cho 2008). Zapping thus affords consumption in a given time interval of large amounts of content while avoiding what is deemed undesirable. By means of zapping it is possible to accelerate viewing rate, thus making room, by squeezing, for additional time frames. The viewer can “jump” from program to program, that is, from one viewing clock to another, accelerate plot progressions, and squeeze a variety of content into one time unit. Moreover, by using the fast-forward function one can gain control over viewing rhythm by accelerating the program’s inner rhythm. To fast-forward means to move forward through an audio or video recording at a speed faster than that at which it would usually run. The fast-forward function lets the viewer skip unnecessary segments of broadcast content (Ma 2007) or commercials (Carlson 2006). In addition, the fast-forward button permits parents to censor segments that in their opinion are not suitable for children (Huang 2007) and makes it possible to edit content and construct an active mode of media consumption (Srinivas 2002; Johnston 2008). (Still, this is particularly characteristic of the younger generation [Kitch 2003].) By means of the transition between these time intervals, it is possible to squeeze multichannel viewing, to “save” time that is “wasted” on commercials or unwanted content and spend it on more desirable content. Fast-forward also makes it possible to accelerate viewing rates by activating a number of viewing clocks simultaneously (Hassan 2003) according to domestic rhythm (Nathanson 2009), so that domestic spaces that are working under squeezed time pressure will adopt and squeeze television time more easily.

The introduction of the digital video recorder has further intensified privatization of the time sphere and squeezed media time. The option of recording programs opens up much greater possibilities of economical control and time squeezing. The core function of a DVR is to record linear television content onto an internal hard drive, which allows the user to play back—time shift—this content whenever or however he or she pleases. DVRs users can pause and/or replay live television (Carlson 2006). Similar to the “stand-alone” remote control device, the DVR redefines the television viewing experience by means of breaking the interlink between transmission time flow and receptor time flow, supporting an independent media timetable (Lotz 2009). The empowerment afforded by new media implementation (such as TiVo receiver) has been widened further by multichannel digital broadcasting (Elmer 2003). However, nowadays the DVR is still more typical of affluent populations and those who have an advanced approach to information and communications technology (Chan-Olmsted and Chang 2006). The DVR privatizes viewing time schedules according to the media consumer’s personal preferences (Carlson 2006). The usage of a DVR or TiVo makes it possible to record two programs simultaneously while at the same time watching a third program that was previously recorded. This means that a number of clocks can run parallel in the media time sphere, considerably strengthening the media consumer’s control over time schedules. Actually, this might be a case of temporal outsourcing, transferring control over media time schedules to an external time source. As domestic outsourcing of housework attempts to cope with time pressure and the desire to achieve a certain standard of living, we are also witness to the phenomenon of temporal outsourcing. Domestic outsourcing means “that certain domestic services are bought in the market. Outsourcing forms a substitute for one’s own domestic chores, and relieves time pressures by reducing the number of hours needed for running the family household” (De Ruijter 2004, 220). Outsourcing is a strategy to relieve the double burden of paid and domestic work; it enables households to reduce the time needed for domestic chores and caregiving (De Ruijter and Van der Lippe 2007) and to save time (Van der Lippe, Tijdens, and De Ruijter 2004; De Ruijter and Van der Lippe 2009). The almost immediate effect is discharging from social and communal contexts (Vered 2002). Thus, self-constructing of time rhythm maximizes the ability to “keep up” with multichannel TV overload and to make room for more media consumption.

sec.title: The Israeli Case
sec.p: As noted before, the three features of media time squeezing were initiated as part of television and the new media revolution. Similar to the agenda of European regulators in recent years (Iosifidis 2006), the Israeli authorities—through the Israeli Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting—promoted a promedia digitalization agenda.2

In the Israeli case, the process ripened in July 2000, when the first Israeli satellite broadcast was launched. It was expanded in January 2001, as the Israeli Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting endorsed digital broadcasting via cables. Thus, a decade after cable TV was introduced to Israeli consumers, digital broadcasting came into effect.

During the years 2000 and 2008, the Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting published nine annual reports, elaborating a regulatory vision, decisions, and actions (Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting and the Authority for Regulating Public Broadcasting 2001, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008, 2010). An analysis of these reports reveals some interesting trends with regard to the establishment of digital TV. First, between July 2000 and December 2004, we were witness to a gradual decline of nondigital cable TV subscribers (a 3 percent average rate of decline per year). Yet at the same time we can identify a gradual increase of digital cable TV subscribers (125 percent average rate of growth per year) and of satellite TV consumers (169 percent average rate of growth per year). Hence, it seems that multichannel TV subscribers prefer digital subscriptions over nondigital ones. Second, during the years 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003, and 2004, the diffusion rates of digital subscribers (from all subscribers) were 7 percent, 34 percent, 47 percent, 50 percent, and 53 percent (respectively), with an average of 38 percent per year. Figure 1 demonstrates the diffusion of digital television in Israel.

sec.p: In 2005, nearly 75 percent of all multichannel television subscribers were hooked up to digital television, and it seems that by 2010 Israeli analog broadcasting will cease completely. Incidentally, compare this to Britain, where within three short years of its launch digital television was diffused to 35 percent of households by 2001 (Weber and Evans 2002).

However, despite the efforts to promote the introduction of digital television for the benefit of cable TV and satellite consumers, the time perception of the regulator has not changed. The basic guiding principle of the Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting is that “the broadcasting field has a great influence on shaping the image of Israeli society and enjoys wide public exposure, especially regarding the amount of free time the Israeli public devotes to watching programs” (Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting and the Authority for Regulating Public Broadcasting 2004, 20). The free time of the Israeli public that is devoted to broadcasts is measured by the Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting by means of examining “broadcast time limits,” “first broadcasting hour debts,” “length of broadcast time,” and so on (Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting and the Authority for Regulating Public Broadcasting 2003, 86, 130). Furthermore, supervision over the broadcast of local productions, for example, is based on multiplying estimates of “basic broadcasting time” by number of subscribers.3 In other words, supervision of the broadcast schedule is effected according to a model based on twenty-four-hour broadcasting calculations. However, the temporary regulatory model is just getting more complicated. “Section 29.10 of the license states that at least half the broadcast time of local productions will deal with topics pertinent to the Israeli way of life, the Israeli experience and the cultural and social experience of the Russian-speaking population in the State of Israel” (Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting and the Authority for Regulating Public Broadcasting 2003, 110). That is, the Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting examines not only the percentage of broadcast time of local productions as computed from the total amount of broadcasting but also the percentages of broadcasting time of these productions regarding their content. This means that the Israeli regulator continues to maintain an attitude of cultural, collective flow of linear time. Acting according to a linear time perception means the creation of a synchronic collective (Hogne 2004) and a communal cultural construction (Fahlgren 2009).

The adoption of a more liberal approach to time perception has put down roots in the supervision of the extent of advertising in cable and satellite channels. Initially it was determined that “the licensee will not sell or apportion more than 30% of total broadcasting time to commercials or promos for a client, either directly or indirectly” (Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting and the Authority for Regulating Public Broadcasting 2003, 150). However, later “in Decision Number 1-5/2006 from 9.3.06 after a hearing and a year’s trial period, the council removed the limitation of broadcasting time of commercials, promos and sponsorship per broadcast hour” (Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting and the Authority for Regulating Public Broadcasting 2010, 44). It seems, then, that the source of this liberality is not related to a desire to improve the viewing quality of the consumer but rather an attempt to ease up on broadcasting corporations. “The removal of the limitation was meant to afford designated channel broadcasters more flexibility in incorporating commercials, especially during peak viewing hours on these channels” (Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting and the Authority for Regulating Public Broadcasting 2008, 63). In this case, too, a linear time perception is implemented since the regulatory dialogue of time reflects the myth of progress, moving forward to the future and modernization (Zerubavel 1981; Leccardi 1999).

As opposed to managing time in the advertising field, the time supervision of “adult” broadcasting content is of a much more rigid nature. “In the framework of its decisions, the council has determined that the possibility of purchasing broadcasts for adults by a PPV service will be provided only to subscribers who have specifically requested them from the licensee. . . . Regarding the length of the programs, the council has determined that the maximum amount of time that the licensee is allowed to offer to its subscribers as one payment package will not exceed seven hours. This directive allows the licensee to also offer its subscribers a PayPerNight all-night package” (Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting and the Authority for Regulating Public Broadcasting 2004, 62). In 2005 the council also imposed these directives on adult broadcasts in the framework of VOD services and later subjected all channels offering sexually explicit broadcasts to time restrictions determined by the council (Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting and the Authority for Regulating Public Broadcasting 2010, 32).

Incidentally, the most stringent directive of broadcast time management is related to times of emergency, when as part of preparation for war in Israel the state authorities are able to take over the entire broadcasting time spectrum.4 Hence, there is a deep mental gap between the administrative possibilities of the time spectrum made possible by digital technology, including its variety of media applications, and the time perceptions held by the regulator. While the regulator encourages (and is even proud of) the rapid and powerful diffusion of digital television in Israel, thus opening the way for asynchronic media consumption and control of and direction of time flow, supervision over multichannel broadcast quality continues to follow a model based on calculating the number of broadcasting hours in a day. This means that while the media consumer is technologically and culturally open to squeezing various types of broadcasting content according to his or her preferences at a particular time, the regulator continues to supervise that same time interval as though it were linear and not subject to squeezing by the media consumer. The result is that the Israeli regulator has not adopted digital time squeeze, apparently because the social function of linear time is to gird the governing, regulation, and coordination of people and their actions. For linear time to function as a means of governing, disciplining strategies have to be developed (Fahlgren 2009).

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: The relationship between media technology and neoliberalism has generated a variety of old–new time concepts, among other things the time perception of “the faster the better” (Hassan 2007), real-time “simultaneity” (Hassan 2003), a “timeless time,” a nontime where everything happens simultaneously (Castells 1996), open future (Adam 2003), and time frames of action (the time frames of action are compressed to zero time; Adam 2003). It also seems that the various technological advances promote a constant sense of “time shortage” (Putnam 2000; Schwartz 2004; Goodin et al. 2005) that has been awarded different names, such as chronic time pressure (Szollos 2009), time crunch (e.g., Zuzanek 2004), time deficit (e.g., Bianchi et al. 2005), time famine (Robinson and Godbey 1999), time poverty (e.g., De Graaf 2003), time pressure (e.g., Teuchmann, Totterdell, and Parker 1999), time scarcity (Hirsch 1976), time sickness (Dossey 1982), time stress (Csikszentmihalyi 1997), and time squeeze (e.g., Jacobs and Gerson 2004). The influence of chronic time pressure on television and new media is interlinked with the notion of time squeezing. Basically, the diffusion of digital and multichannel applications has made the privatization of television time sphere possible. Yet at the same time the regulations over new media are based on state time management, constructing time according to traditional, linear, nontechnological options. Moreover, even though neoliberalism has promoted systematic deregulation and privatization, in the arena of television and new media one cannot overlook the dualism sustained between technological vision and cultural substantiation.

To conclude, media digitalization has afforded the creation of dynamic time consumption. Consumers can determine if and how they choose to squeeze media time. They can obtain a synchronic versus asynchronic timetable, they can control time flow directions (by means of rewind, pause, start over), and they can accelerate viewing rates (by means of fast-forward, zapping). One way or another, media time squeezing promotes the deconstruction of temporal hegemony. Similar to former hegemonial management of time by the church (Kertzer 1980) and the unions (Bluedorn 2009), media regulators strive to culturally control time. Ironically, the ones who paved the way to self-constructing of time, supported by time shifting and time squeezing, are having difficulties adjusting to the new environment of television and new media. But this takes us to a different study.

At this juncture it is important to clarify that the social implications of the above-mentioned phenomena were dealt with as early as 1958 by John Kenneth Galbraith in his book The Affluent Society and have since been discussed in hundreds of books and articles. According to Galbraith, the affluent society changed consumerism into a yardstick for measuring social achievement. The more a person consumes, the more advanced he or she is perceived to be. Furthermore, the consumption of a certain amount of goods does not result in the reduction of the benefit to be derived from additional consumption. The outcome is that the individual can never reach consumer satiation but must increase his or her consumption, thus strengthening production. The great emphasis placed on overconsumption of products and services by private consumers has drastically increased the amount of resources set aside by corporations to cultivate consumerism by means of advertising, marketing, and product sales (Parker 2005), thus creating gaps between private consumption and public supply (Smart 2009). However, the assimilation of the affluent society did not take place as a result of political pressure, economic leadership, or economic entrepreneurship but rather arose from the daily routine of social life, as people bought new ranges of consumer products, were employed in new types of mechanized factories, and moved into new kinds of housing estates (Savage 2009).

The statutory regulatory body of multichannel TV in Israel is a public council established under the Telecommunications Law of 1982. The council is headed by a chairman, who represents the Ministry of Communications and is the only member whose employment by the council is his or her primary activity. The council is a member of the European Platform of Regulatory Authorities.

Regulation 21 (a)(3) of Bezeq Regulations (Procedures and Conditions to Awarding a License to Satellite Broadcasts) of 1998 (hereafter, “satellite procedures”) requires the satellite company to include original broadcasts of local productions to an extent that in twenty-four hours will not be less than the following percentage: 2 percent of basic broadcasting time—when they reach fifty thousand subscribers. Basic broadcasting time is defined as “the time received by multiplying three broadcast hours a day by the number of Hebrew-speaking programs that the licensee is required to broadcast according to Regulation (20a) unless determined otherwise by the Council. The number of channels in Hebrew that the licensee is required to broadcast according to Regulation (20a) is three channels” (Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting and the Authority for Regulating Public Broadcasting 2002, 133).

“As part of the State of Israel’s preparations for the American Army’s activities in Iraq, the authorities decided that in case of a missile attack on Israel, broadcasts on all cable and satellite channels would cease and a five-minute instructional film of the IDF spokesman would be broadcast in their place. . . . According to the recommendation of the Attorney General it was decided to limit the blackout of all channels to a period of 15 minutes, while leaving it up to the authorities to decide whether to extend it beyond that time frame” (Council for Cable TV and Satellite Broadcasting and the Authority for Regulating Public Broadcasting 2003, 65).
